newsitem.title: USA: NYS monitor wants bonanza used to pay down debt.
newsitem.headline: NYS monitor wants bonanza used to pay down debt.

text.p: The New York State Comptroller on Tuesday recommended that a projected $1.6 billion windfall for fiscal 1997 be used to pay down debt and boost a fund that could be drawn upon in emergencies.

H. Carl McCall, who spoke at a gathering of the New York State Newspaper Publishers Association in Albany, also told reporters that the Pataki Administration's capital plan would raise backdoor borrowing, a criticism he has made previously.

Voters never got a chance to specifically approve about $21 billion of the state's approximately $30 billion of debt outstanding, and by 2001, the amount of bonds that would be borrowed without their explicit say so rises to $28.6 billion under the governor's plan, McCall said.
The state's top fiscal monitor estimated debt service will rise to almost $4 billion by 2001 to 2002 from $2.8 billion at present.

Gov George Pataki has proposed depositing about $65 million in the state's Rainy Day Fund, which could be used to help stabilize the state's finances if there were a downturn, but his plan fell short in McCall's eyes.

"I think we could easily double that and at the same time look at a reduction in debt service," he said, though he noted that there is a limit on the maximum deposit the state can make, a number that he did not have at hand.

McCall declined to recommend how much of New York State's whopping surplus, which mainly comes from stunning profits earned by Wall Street's financial industry, should be directed towards debt service.
"I have not put a number on the table, I'm just simply saying that that number ought to be put on the table by the governor in terms of a prudent way to manage our finances over a longer-term."

The fiscal monitor, a Democrat, who has weighed running for governor, again blasted Pataki for proposing huge new tax cuts, which if added to the ones already approved, would slash state revenues by $8 billion in 1998.
